content: Yes, some bird species in Yellowstone National Park are considered endangered or threatened. The trumpeter swan and peregrine falcon are both considered threatened, while the bald eagle and whooping crane are classified as endangered. The Yellowstone population of the gray-crowned rosy finch is also considered rare and a significant conservation concern. Additionally, habitat loss, climate change, and other human-driven factors threaten many bird species in the park and around the world.
